policy_description: The Government of Canada provides CAD 500 million to Sustainable Development Technology Canada (SDTC) to invest with the private sector to establish first-of-kind large demonstration-scale facilities for the production of next-generation biofuels. The funding to the SDTC is co-managed by Natural Resources Canada and Environment Canada.
Summary: The Government of Canada is allocating CAD 500 million to Sustainable Development Technology Canada (SDTC) to partner with the private sector in creating large-scale demonstration facilities for next-generation biofuel production. This funding is co-managed by Natural Resources Canada and Environment Canada.

policy_description: The INDC of Suriname included commitments to improve sustainable forest management withe goal of enhancing the country's carbon sink potential, but no targets in terms of absolute or relative GHG emissions by 2030. IEA/IRENA Global Renewable Energy Policies and Measures Database © OECD/IEA and IRENA, [November 2020]
Summary: Suriname's Intended Nationally Determined Contributions (INDC) focus on enhancing sustainable forest management to increase the country's carbon sink potential. However, the INDC does not specify any targets for absolute or relative greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions by the year 2030.

policy_description: "Under this program, manufacturers (importers) are mandated to produce and sell energy efficient products from the outset. This program is Koreas core energy efficiency standards & labeling scheme. Energy Efficiency Label and Standard Program enables consumers to identify energy efficient products easily by (1) mandatory indication of energy efficiency grade from 1st to 5th grade (2) mandatory reporting, and (3) applying MEPS (Minimum Energy Performance Standard)" (Kemco, 2011).
Summary: The program requires manufacturers and importers in Korea to produce and sell energy-efficient products. It serves as the country's main energy efficiency standards and labeling initiative, allowing consumers to easily recognize energy-efficient items through mandatory energy efficiency grades (ranging from 1 to 5), required reporting, and the implementation of Minimum Energy Performance Standards (MEPS).

policy_description: Promote investment incentives under articles 11 of Egypt's Investment Law No. 72/2017 and 10 of its Executive Regulations issued by Prime Ministerial Decree no. 2310/2017 including renewable energy projects, agriculture, livestock.
Summary: The policy aims to encourage investment in Egypt by leveraging the incentives outlined in Article 11 of the Investment Law No. 72/2017 and Article 10 of its Executive Regulations (Prime Ministerial Decree No. 2310/2017). It specifically targets sectors such as renewable energy, agriculture, and livestock to attract more investment.

policy_description: The pathway defines the countrys climate ambition with an absolute emission reduction target of 18 percent compared to the UAEs updated second Nationally Determined Contribution (NDC) under the Paris Agreement by 2030, 60 percent by 2040, and 100 percent by 2050, compared to 2019.
Summary: The policy outlines the UAE's climate goals, aiming for a reduction in greenhouse gas emissions of 18% by 2030, 60% by 2040, and achieving net-zero emissions by 2050, all compared to 2019 levels, in line with the country's updated Nationally Determined Contribution (NDC) under the Paris Agreement.

policy_description: The purpose of PROMOBILITY is to reduce travel times, increase road safety and improve the health and access of the population to employment and service areas, especially for lower-income users, as well as to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. and local air pollutants, helping to raise the quality of life of the inhabitants and the competitiveness of cities, through motorized and non-motorized modes of transport.
Summary: The PROMOBILITY policy aims to enhance transportation efficiency by reducing travel times and improving road safety. It focuses on increasing access to employment and services for lower-income individuals while also aiming to decrease greenhouse gas emissions and local air pollutants. Ultimately, the policy seeks to improve the quality of life for residents and boost urban competitiveness through both motorized and non-motorized transportation options.

policy_description: The UK Net Zero Research and Innovation Framework entails a government investment exceeding £4 billion from 2022 to 2025. This funding is dedicated to the development of technologies crucial for achieving the nation's net zero goals. It emphasizes supporting businesses within the green economy and addressing urgent challenges that the market may struggle to tackle independently.
Summary: The UK Net Zero Research and Innovation Framework is a government initiative that will invest over £4 billion from 2022 to 2025. This funding aims to develop essential technologies for reaching the country's net zero goals, with a focus on supporting green economy businesses and addressing urgent challenges that the market may find difficult to resolve on its own.

The second goal is to set more stringent efficiency levels and carbon monoxide emission standards for the same appliances. These emission standards are specific for each type of appliances: stove, solid fuel burner with a glass door, household appliance with slow heat release, wood pellet stove, boiler-stove, boiler, open fire. Summary: This initiative allocates CAD 10.26 million to support research focused on decreasing methane emissions in the oil and gas industry.

policy_description: The most important recent development in Korea, which has gained strong public attention, is Particular Matter Emissions Control Policy and its associated implementation plans. The plans include large subsidies for disseminating eco-friendly cars and EV charging infrastructures and early replacement subsidies for old diesel vehicles. Tthe PM Emissions Control Policy concerns only with air quality and environmental improvement.
Summary: The recent "Particular Matter Emissions Control Policy" in Korea focuses on improving air quality and environmental conditions. It includes significant subsidies for promoting eco-friendly vehicles and electric vehicle (EV) charging infrastructure, as well as incentives for replacing old diesel vehicles. This policy has garnered considerable public attention.

policy_description: Poland's long-debated Renewable Energy Act was adopted in February 2015. After going through two amendments, the new law became effective in July 2016. The Law substitutes an auction system for the green certificate system. The first auction was held on December 30, 2016, and the results were released in early January 2017. Additional auctions were held in the spring of 2017, and more were planned for the summer and the fall. The Act was unclear about whether combining an auction contract with other forms of public funding would violate the EU's standards on fair competition, therefore the final two 2017 auction rounds were annulled. These errors served as the impetus for the following revision to the Act, which became effective on June 29, 2018. The auction system was amended by the June 2018 legislation, which also effectively unblocked it. To add new renewable energy capacity to the system, the Energy Regulatory Office (URE) of Poland is required to plan and conduct auction rounds by the end of 2018 and early 2019. Auction technology baskets were updated by the June 2018 modification.
Summary: Poland's Renewable Energy Act, adopted in February 2015 and amended twice, transitioned from a green certificate system to an auction system starting in July 2016. The first auction took place in December 2016, with subsequent auctions in early 2017. However, uncertainties regarding the compatibility of auction contracts with EU competition standards led to the annulment of the last two auctions in 2017. policy_description: The Decision contains provisions for funding, incentives (including a feed-in tariff and import duty exemption) and investment in the construction of solar power projects. It also sets out the responsibilities of the relevant state agencies and ministries including the Ministry of Industry and Trade, the Ministry of Planning and Investment and the Ministry of Finance.
Summary: The policy outlines funding and incentives for solar power projects, including a feed-in tariff and import duty exemption. It details the roles of key state agencies, such as the Ministry of Industry and Trade, the Ministry of Planning and Investment, and the Ministry of Finance, in overseeing these initiatives.

policy_description: Enova offers investment aid to energy measures in buildings. The aid is given to measures that reduce energy use and converts energy sources to renewable ones. IEA/IRENA Global Renewable Energy Policies and Measures Database © OECD/IEA and IRENA, [November 2020]
Summary: Enova provides financial support for energy efficiency improvements and the transition to renewable energy sources in buildings. This aid targets initiatives that aim to reduce energy consumption and promote the use of renewable energy.

policy_description: The PDP8 initiative charts a new course in energy development, prioritizing renewable sources. It aims to boost renewable power capacity, targeting 48% by 2030 and 65.8-71% by 2050. Simultaneously, it plans to phase out coal power entirely by 2050, reducing its share from 20% in 2030 to 0%.
Summary: The PDP8 initiative focuses on advancing renewable energy development, with goals to increase renewable power capacity to 48% by 2030 and 65.8-71% by 2050. It also aims to eliminate coal power completely by 2050, decreasing its contribution from 20% in 2030 to 0%.

policy_description:
The Energy Market Authority (EMA), the Ministry of the Environment, Water Resources (MEWR) and SP Group today announced three new initiatives aimed at empowering households to use electricity more efficiently. These initiatives are:
Advanced meters that will give all household consumers access to their half-hourly electricity usage via the SP Utilities mobile app
Enhanced SP Utilities mobile app to encourage households to adopt sustainable habits and save electricity
Customised reports on households electricity consumption and energy saving tips
Summary:
The Energy Market Authority (EMA), the Ministry of the Environment, Water Resources (MEWR), and SP Group have launched three initiatives to help households use electricity more efficiently. These include: 

1. Advanced meters providing access to half-hourly electricity usage through the SP Utilities mobile app.
2. An enhanced SP Utilities app designed to promote sustainable habits and electricity savings.
3. Customized reports on electricity consumption along with energy-saving tips for households.

This law was abolished by the Energy Transition Law (2015).
Summary: The "National Programme for Sustainable Use of Energy 2014-2018," adopted on April 28, 2014, builds upon an earlier version from 2009-2012 and establishes specific indicators to be achieved by 2018. However, this program was later abolished by the Energy Transition Law in 2015.

policy_description: The programme is structured around two phases: piloting (20152019) and full-scale implementation (20202030). The key measures taken under the programme include: public transport system improvement, investments in energy-efficient buses, investments in infrastructure and improved planning. The projected GHG mitigation effect of the programme is 18.673 MtCO2e over the period 20202030 (CAT, 2019:37).
Summary: The policy is divided into two phases: a pilot phase from 2015 to 2019 and a full-scale implementation phase from 2020 to 2030. Key actions include enhancing the public transport system, investing in energy-efficient buses, improving infrastructure, and better planning. It is projected to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 18.6 to 73 million tons of CO2 equivalent during the 2020-2030 period.

policy_description: In 1992 the Flemish Region started an action programme to promote Company Transportation/ Commuter plans. These plans mainly consist of bus services and carpooling, on the level of the individual company or several neighbouring enterprises. Mainly large companies situated in urban areas participated in this programme on a voluntary basis (about 20 companies during the period 1994-99) and received financial support from the Flemish Region. The Flemish government has created a "commuterfund". Companies and non-profit organisations which develop a mobility action plan in order to support a significant modal shift among their employees can get 50% funding of these initiatives from the "commuterfund" during the first 4 years. In each Flemish province a mobility desk was created, where companies can get assistance and advice on the development of their commuter plans. In addition, companies pay back at least 56-64.9% of the cost of a public transport season ticket to their employees. If the company decides to pay back 80% of the ticket price, the authorities pay back the remaining 20%. IEA/IRENA Global Renewable Energy Policies and Measures Database © OECD/IEA and IRENA, [November 2020]

The initiative, which was voluntary and attracted around 20 large urban companies between 1994 and 1999, provided financial support through a "commuterfund." policy_description: "In 1997, the Government of Canada introduced a Model National Energy Code for Buildings (MNEBC 1997), which augmented the existing National Building Code with a set of energy-specific criteria on top of the National Building Codes (NBC) existing health and safety requirements. National Building Codes in Canada do not have force in law, and are adopted (or adapted) by jurisdictions (provinces and territories) on an individual basis" (IEA, 2011) IEA/IRENA Global Renewable Energy Policies and Measures Database © OECD/IEA and IRENA, [November 2020]
Summary: In 1997, the Government of Canada introduced the Model National Energy Code for Buildings (MNEBC 1997), which added energy-specific criteria to the existing National Building Code (NBC) focused on health and safety. The NBC itself does not have legal force and is implemented by individual provinces and territories in Canada.

policy_description: The Climate Change Policy Coordination Commission (CCPCC) is a coordination body between the central administration, autonomous communities and local authorities for all matters related to climate change. Royal Decree 1823/2011, which restructures the ministerial departments, establishes that the chair of the Commission is the Secretary of State for the Environment.
Summary: The Climate Change Policy Coordination Commission (CCPCC) serves as a coordinating body for the central administration, autonomous communities, and local authorities on climate change issues. Established under Royal Decree 1823/2011, the Commission is chaired by the Secretary of State for the Environment.

policy_description: The tax reform dictates carbon taxation of new car purchases based on Nitrogen oxide (NOx) (heavy) and Field Electron (FE) (more light) emissions, according to Fuel Economy labelling information. The reform also includes a "green tax," a US$5 tax per ton of CO2 emitted from thermal powerplants.
Summary: The tax reform introduces a carbon tax on new car purchases that is based on emissions of Nitrogen oxide (NOx) and Field Electron (FE) as indicated by Fuel Economy labels. Additionally, it imposes a "green tax" of $5 per ton of CO2 emitted by thermal power plants.

policy_description: Since July 2017, the Federal Government has started funding heat network operators, aiming at either creating low-tenperature heat networks with a high proportion of renewable energies and waste heat or transforming their existing networks into similar, low-CO2 networks. The funding can be provided for covering the cost of feasibility studies as well as the costs of the realisation of the heat networks. IEA/IRENA Global Renewable Energy Policies and Measures Database © OECD/IEA and IRENA, [November 2020]
Summary: Since July 2017, the Federal Government has been funding heat network operators to establish low-temperature heat networks that utilize a high percentage of renewable energy and waste heat, or to convert existing networks into low-CO2 alternatives. The funding supports both feasibility studies and the implementation costs of these heat networks.

policy_description: This law amends the 2003 law on alternative energy sources. It sets the rules for quotas of renewable energy and the related auction and feed-in tariff schemes. Summary: This policy updates the 2003 law concerning alternative energy sources by establishing rules for renewable energy quotas, as well as auction and feed-in tariff schemes related to those quotas.

policy_description: This policy seeks to increase the share of EVs in Colombia's transport system. It sets the target of reaching 600,000 vehicles by 2030
Summary: The policy aims to boost the adoption of electric vehicles (EVs) in Colombia's transportation sector, with a goal of achieving 600,000 EVs by the year 2030.

policy_description:
With the ratification of the Kigali Amendment, group II parties commit to peak HFCs consumption by 2024 and to gradually phase down in line with the following schedule:
(i) 2024 to 2028: 100 per cent
(ii) 2029 to 2034: 90 per cent
(iii) 2035 to 2039: 70 per cent
(iv) 2040 to 2044: 50 per cent
(v) 2045 and thereafter: 20 per cent
Summary: The Kigali Amendment requires group II parties to peak their HFCs consumption by 2024 and progressively reduce it according to the following schedule: 100% from 2024 to 2028, 90% from 2029 to 2034, 70% from 2035 to 2039, 50% from 2040 to 2044, and 20% from 2045 onwards.

policy_description:
The Resolution of the President No. PP-4477 of 2019 on the Strategy for the Transition to a Green Economy for 2019-2030 adopted a strategy of comprehensive measures aimed at transforming, modernising and diversifying the basic sectors of the economy and balanced socio-economic development of territories.
The resolution includes the following targets:
	Reduction of specific greenhouse gas emissions per unit of gross domestic product by 10% from the level of 2010 by 2030
	Doubling energy efficiency and reducing the carbon intensity of gross domestic product
	?Further development of renewable energy sources with bringing their share to more than 25% of the total electricity generation
	Ensuring access to modern, inexpensive and reliable energy supply to 100% of the population and sectors of the economy
	Modernization of the infrastructure of industrial enterprises, ensuring their sustainability by increasing energy efficiency by at least 20% and wider use of clean and environmentally friendly technologies and industrial processes
	A significant increase in the efficiency of water use in all sectors of the economy, the introduction of drip irrigation technologies on an area of up to 1 million hectares and an increase in yield to 20-40% of the crops cultivated on them;
	Increase to 20 - 25% of the average productivity of production of the main types of food agricultural products.?
Summary:
The Resolution of the President No. PP-4477 of 2019 outlines a comprehensive strategy for transitioning to a green economy from 2019 to 2030. The key targets include:

- Reducing greenhouse gas emissions per unit of GDP by 10% from 2010 levels by 2030.
- Doubling energy efficiency and lowering carbon intensity of GDP.
- Increasing the share of renewable energy sources to over 25% of total electricity generation.
- Ensuring 100% access

policy_description:
For the purpose of creating short rotation forests for biomass production over 100,000 ha by 2020, the Establishment Plan of Short Rotation Forests for Biomass Production was established in 2009. About 6,116 ha of short rotation forests
for biomass production have been established through fast growing species such as the tulip tree and various other types of poplars as of 2009. (Source: http://unfccc.int/resource/docs/natc/kornc3.pdf)
Summary: The Establishment Plan of Short Rotation Forests for Biomass Production was initiated in 2009 with the goal of creating over 100,000 hectares of short rotation forests by 2020. By 2009, approximately 6,116 hectares had been established using fast-growing species, including tulip trees and various poplars.

policy_description: Executive. Adresses both adaptation and mitigation. Variety of policy measures concerning all sectors.
Summary: The policy is an executive initiative that focuses on both adaptation and mitigation strategies. It encompasses a range of policy measures applicable to all sectors.

policy_description: Increase the share of renewables to 30% of the total energy consumption by 2025.
Summary: The policy aims to raise the proportion of renewable energy sources to 30% of total energy consumption by the year 2025.

policy_description: Law 26.473. This law prohibits both import and commercialization of incandescent light bulbs for residential use throughout the country
Summary: Law 26.473 prohibits the importation and sale of incandescent light bulbs for residential use across the country.

policy_description: This Decree establishes the technical and administrative conditions for certification of energy efficiency of buildings and the methodology for calculating its energy efficiency rating. The purpose of the basic procedure is to promote energy efficiency, using information on the energy characteristics of buildings, in the form of an energy performance certificate that must be provided to buyers and users.
Summary: This Decree outlines the technical and administrative requirements for certifying the energy efficiency of buildings, including the methodology for determining their energy efficiency rating. Its main goal is to enhance energy efficiency by providing information on the energy characteristics of buildings through an energy performance certificate, which is required to be given to buyers and users.

policy_description:
The Basic Energy Plan is a policy document formulated by the Government of Japan under the Basic Act on Energy Policy, which entered into force in June 2002. The plan presents the basic principles of Japans energy policy, namely, safety, energy security, improving economic efficiency, and environment suitability, and shows the basic direction of the energy policy. Since 2003, a new strategic energy plan has been developed every 3-4 years.
METI's 4th Strategic Energy Plan (Basic Energy Plan), released in 2014 calls for nuclear energy to account for 20%-22% of power generation by 2030, with 22%-24% coming from renewable energy sources, while coal's share will be reduced to 26%, LNG's to 27% and oil's to just 3%.
The report, by the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry (METI), says that total energy demand in Japan will increase from 940 TWh in 2013 to 980.8 TWh in 2030.

It outlines the fundamental principles of Japan's energy policy, focusing on safety, energy security, economic efficiency, and environmental suitability. policy_description: Adaptation / flood resilience
Summary: The adaptation/flood resilience policy focuses on strategies and measures to enhance the ability of communities, infrastructure, and ecosystems to withstand and recover from flooding events. This includes implementing flood prevention measures, improving infrastructure, restoring natural habitats, and promoting sustainable land use practices. The policy aims to reduce vulnerability, protect lives and property, and ensure the long-term sustainability of affected areas in the face of climate change and increasing flood risks.

policy_description:
Art.1 creates the Environmental and Insurance Sustainability Programme (PROSAS). The programme's objective is to foster investments in new forestry ventures and in the extensions of existing forests which take place in accordance with Law no. 25.080. The programme aims to promote both forestation and enrichment of the native forest with the aim of increasing forest plantations from 1.3 million hectares to 2 million hectares by 2030. To reach 2 million hectares by 2030 would mean expanding forested areas by 62,000 hectares per year.
SPANISH: Esta Resolución conjunta crea el Programa de Sustentabilidad Ambiental y Seguros (PROSAS), con el objeto de promover las inversiones en nuevos emprendimientos forestales y en las ampliaciones de los bosques existentes que se efectúen en el marco de lo dispuesto por la Ley Nº 25.080 de Inversiones para Bosques Cultivados.
Summary: The Environmental and Insurance Sustainability Programme (PROSAS) aims to encourage investments in new forestry projects and the expansion of existing forests, in line with Law No. 25.080. The program's goal is to increase forest area from 1.3 million hectares to 2 million hectares by 2030, requiring an annual expansion of 62,000 hectares.

Original title: ??????????. Act on Promotion of Global Warming Countermeasures "entered into the force on 9 October 1998" and "serves as a framework for tackling global warming with a coalition among central government, local government, Businesses, and citizens." (LCS.RNet, 2012)
The 2010 act states its purpose as "... In order to contribute to the global greenhouse gas emissions reduction and bring about a society that emits as little greenhouse gas as possible, Japan will promote global warming countermeasures while ensuring economic growth, stable employment and stable supply of energy." It further provides Mid and long term goals for "Greenhouse gas emissions reduction targets:
-- A reduction of 25% below 1990 level by 2020, premised on the establishment of a fair and effective international framework by all major economies and agreement on their ambitious targets
-- A reduction of 80% below 1990 level by 2050, striving to share with all economies the vision of the goal of achieving at least 50% reduction of global emissions by 2050."
The Kyoto Protocol Target Achievement Plan (2005), mandated by this Act, stipulated the measures necessary for ensuring the achievement of Japan's 6% reduction commitment under the Kyoto Protocol. It has been approved in the cabinet and has been revised twice, once in 2006 and then in 2008. Summary: ESOS (Energy Savings Opportunity Scheme) is a required energy assessment program for qualifying organizations in the UK, overseen by the Environment Agency.

Ministeri Decree No 1567K/21/MEM/2018
Renewable electricity target of 23% by 2025.
Summary: Ministerial Decree No. 1567K/21/MEM/2018 establishes a target for renewable electricity in the energy mix, aiming for 23% of electricity generation to come from renewable sources by the year 2025.

policy_description:
The General Environmental Law sets the legal framework for the management of environment in Peru. It establishes principles and basic norms to ensure the protection of the environment. It aims to improve the quality of life of the population, and to promote sustainable development in Peru.
This law regulates activities and actions related to environmental protection.
Summary: The General Environmental Law in Peru provides a legal framework for environmental management, establishing principles and norms to protect the environment. Its goals include enhancing the quality of life for the population and promoting sustainable development while regulating activities related to environmental protection.

policy_description: The Energy Efficiency and Conservation Act creates an Inter-Agency Energy Efficiency and Conservation Committee (IAEECC). This agency will develop projects aiming to reduce energy costs in state-owned and leased buildings and facilities. (source: Climate Action Tracker, https://climateactiontracker.org/countries/philippines/current-policy-projections/)
Summary: The Energy Efficiency and Conservation Act establishes the Inter-Agency Energy Efficiency and Conservation Committee (IAEECC), which is responsible for creating projects designed to lower energy costs in state-owned and leased buildings and facilities.

policy_description: Renewable energy production of 5% of total energy use, to be achieved by 2020.
Summary: The policy aims to achieve a renewable energy production target of 5% of total energy use by the year 2020.

policy_description: The program encourages the use of methane recovery (biogas) technologies at confined animal feeding operations that manage manure as liquids or slurries. These technologies reduce methane emissions while achieving other environmental benefits. Although the overall impact of AgSTAR on GHG emissions has been comparatively small on a national scale, livestock producers in the dairy and swine sector have demonstrated that the practices can reduce GHG emissions and achieve other pollution control benefits while increasing farm profitability. (http://unfccc.int/resource/docs/natc/usa_nc5.pdf)
Summary: The program promotes the adoption of methane recovery (biogas) technologies at confined animal feeding operations that handle manure as liquids or slurries. These technologies help decrease methane emissions and provide additional environmental advantages. While the overall impact of AgSTAR on national greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions is limited, dairy and swine producers have shown that these practices can effectively reduce GHG emissions, enhance pollution control, and boost farm profitability.

policy_description:
"This legislation has the purpose of protecting and improving soil quality, especially in areas deemed at risk of degradation due to climate change. It amends a number of existing laws and regulations by promoting sustainability and adaptation to climate change.
The Ministry of Forest and Water Affairs is tasked with undertaking necessary measures by co-operating with related public agencies and institutions and non-governmental organizations on areas in which land degradation has been identified due to climate change or human settlement, agriculture or industrial activities. "
Summary: The legislation aims to protect and enhance soil quality, particularly in regions vulnerable to degradation from climate change. It modifies existing laws to promote sustainability and climate adaptation. The Ministry of Forest and Water Affairs is responsible for implementing measures in collaboration with public agencies, NGOs, and other stakeholders in areas affected by land degradation from climate change, human settlement, agriculture, or industrial activities.

policy_description: At the heart of the monitoring process for the energy transition is the Monitoring Report, which is published on an annual basis. The purpose of this report is to condense the reams of statistical information on energy that have been collected into a smaller, more manageable number of selected indicators. This information provides a fact-based overview of the current status of progress with regard to implementation of the energy reforms. The main source of this data is official energy statistics.
Summary: The Monitoring Report is an annual publication that summarizes extensive statistical data on energy, distilling it into key indicators. Its purpose is to provide a clear, fact-based overview of the progress being made in implementing energy reforms, using official energy statistics as the primary data source.

policy_description: This law creates a new subsidy model to make renewables investments more attractive, including a 50% rebate on transmission and distribution tariffs for generators of solar, wind, biomass and cogeneration. This tariff reduction was ammended by law 14,120 on 2021.
Summary: The policy establishes a new subsidy model aimed at encouraging investments in renewable energy by offering a 50% rebate on transmission and distribution tariffs for solar, wind, biomass, and cogeneration generators. This tariff reduction was amended by law 14,120 in 2021.

policy_description: The regulation explains that REDD demonstration activities are implemented by proponents who may be assisted by partners. Proponents are defined as government, forest timber product utility license holders, and managers of customary forest. While partners include government, international organisations, private entities, individuals. The regulation spells out that it is aimed at testing and developing methodologies, technology and institutions to reduce emissions from deforestation and forest degradation. It states clearly what application and approval procedure must be undertaken and defines the maximum period for a demonstration as 5 years.
Summary: The regulation outlines that REDD demonstration activities are carried out by proponents, which include government entities, timber product license holders, and customary forest managers, with the support of various partners like governments, international organizations, private entities, and individuals. The primary goal is to test and develop methodologies, technologies, and institutions aimed at reducing emissions from deforestation and forest degradation. It specifies the application and approval process required for participation and establishes a maximum duration of 5 years for demonstration activities.

policy_description: In compliance with EU laws, the Act of 17 December 2020 on Promoting Electricity Generation in Offshore Wind Farms seeks to increase the production of renewable energy from wind in the Baltic Sea.
Summary: The Act of 17 December 2020 aims to boost renewable energy production from offshore wind farms in the Baltic Sea, aligning with EU regulations.

policy_description:
Executive
Te Kaniva (referring to the traditional travelling method of using stars and daily weather patterns to navigate) outlines the strategic policies for responding to climate change impacts and related disaster risks for the period 2012-2021. Summary: The Executive Te Kaniva policy, covering the period from 2012 to 2021, focuses on strategic responses to climate change impacts and disaster risks. Coordinated by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Trade, Tourism, Environment and Labour, it involved collaboration with various government agencies and support from regional and international organizations. The policy outlines seven thematic goals, each with specific strategies and expected outcomes.

policy_description:
With the ratification of the Kigali Amendment, group II parties commit to peak HFCs consumption by 2024 and to gradually phase down in line with the following schedule:
(i) 2024 to 2028: 100 per cent
(ii) 2029 to 2034: 90 per cent
(iii) 2035 to 2039: 70 per cent
(iv) 2040 to 2044: 50 per cent
(v) 2045 and thereafter: 20 per cent
Summary:
The Kigali Amendment requires group II parties to peak their consumption of hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs) by 2024 and gradually reduce it according to the following schedule: 

- 2024 to 2028: 100% of baseline consumption
- 2029 to 2034: 90% of baseline consumption
- 2035 to 2039: 70% of baseline consumption
- 2040 to 2044: 50% of baseline

policy_description: In June 2017 the parliament approved the law on Energy Efficiency in Buildings to meet the requirements of the EU EPBD Directive. The law makes mandatory certification of new and undergoing renovation residential buildings, the residential buildings obtaining state support for thermo-modernization and all public buildings with the floor area above 250 m2 in line with the EU legislation. It also requires the developers to comply with the minimum energy performance standards (MEPSs) that are effective in the EU. The certificates containing information about the class and other indicators of energy efficiency of the building should be displayed in an accessible for the people place. The owner or developer should also provide the certificate on a request of a potential apartment buyer or a person renting the apartment. (For more details, see reference below.) Summary: In June 2017, the parliament enacted a law on Energy Efficiency in Buildings to align with the EU Energy Performance of Buildings Directive (EPBD). This law mandates certification for new and renovated residential buildings, those receiving state support for energy modernization, and all public buildings over 250 m². Developers must adhere to EU Minimum Energy Performance Standards (MEPS). Energy efficiency certificates must be displayed in accessible locations and provided to potential buyers or renters upon request.

policy_description: Reduce intensity of GHG emissions per unit of GDP by 8-10% or double the target with international support by 2020. Reduce total GHG emissions by at least 1% per year without and 2% with international support by 2030.
Summary: The policy aims to reduce greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions intensity by 8-10% per unit of GDP by 2020, with the possibility of doubling this target through international support. Additionally, it seeks to decrease total GHG emissions by at least 1% annually without international support and by 2% annually with such support by 2030.

policy_description:
Tanzania will reduce greenhouse gas emissions economy wide between 10-20% by 2030
relative to the BAU scenario of 138 - 153 Million tones of carbon dioxide equivalent
(MtCO2e)- gross emissions, depending on the baseline efficiency improvements, consistent
with its sustainable development agenda. The emissions reduction is subject to review
after the first Biennial Update Report (BUR).
Summary: Tanzania aims to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions by 10-20% by 2030, compared to a business-as-usual scenario of 138-153 million tons of carbon dioxide equivalent (MtCO2e). This target aligns with the country's sustainable development goals and will be reviewed following its first Biennial Update Report (BUR).

policy_description:
Legislative
The new renewable energy law establishes more ambitious national renewable energy targets that should reach 20% of total national energy consumption and 40% of total electricity consumption by 2020. Moreover, 20% of energy used in heating and cooling and 10% of energy used in transportation have to come from renewable sources. The new legislation foresees the creation of a Special Renewable Energy Investment Service that will act as an interface between public institutions and investors, annually assess the main challenges to renewable energy deployment and manage the support funding allocation process. Existing remuneration of individual residents in areas where renewable energy projects are running have been amended and replaced by a credit on electricity bills. In fact, the law establishes that a share of the RE concession taxes paid by RE producers to regional and local authorities will will be allocated to local households as a credit on their electricity bill as a way to share the benefits of living nearby a renewable energy generation plant. The renewable energy generation licensing process has also been very much fasten and eased by the regulation that entitles the Regulatory Authority for Energy (RAE) with the assessment and issuance of licences, under the authority of the ministry of Environment, Energy and Climate Change. The whole licensing process can not last over a 30-month period. Moreover, absolute priority is given to RES projects combined with desalination plants, when and only when the RES project is on an island and its capacity does not exceed 25% of the capacity of the desalination plant. The law also tackles the grid infrastructure challenge and implements a timely limited target for the grid utility to connect non-interconnected islands to the main grid. Still, RE projects are not granted grid priority access as grid connection will be established on a first-come first served basis until the network is saturated. The grid utility is compelled to provide grid access within four months after the connection demand has been released. The Law 3851 also establishes a whole new set of feed-in tariffs for electricity from renewable sources, to be found in the Greek FIT article. It mandates that 20% of energy used for heating and cooling, and 10% for transportation, also come from renewable sources. A Special Renewable Energy Investment Service will be established to facilitate public-private collaboration, address challenges in renewable energy deployment, and manage funding allocations.

IEA/IRENA Global Renewable Energy Policies and Measures Database © OECD/IEA and IRENA, [November 2020]
Summary: The Department of Energy (DOE) has identified various technology options to reduce power consumption in standby mode. These options include utilizing lower-power display technologies, implementing cooking sensors that do not require standby power, enhancing power supply and control board efficiency, and incorporating automatic power-down features.

policy_description: "The Australian Government will work with the community to plant 20 million trees by 2020, to re-establish green corridors and urban forests. The 20 Million Trees Programme is part of the national stream of the National Landcare Programme. Under the 20 Million Trees Programme $42.88million (GST exclusive) has been announced across 166 projects to plant more than 13.5 million trees (as at 8 March 2016)."
Summary: The Australian Government's 20 Million Trees Programme aims to plant 20 million trees by 2020 to restore green corridors and urban forests. This initiative is part of the National Landcare Programme, with $42.88 million allocated to 166 projects, resulting in the planting of over 13.5 million trees as of March 8, 2016.

policy_description: The Law for the Strengthening of the Costa Rican Railway Institute (Incofer - Instituto costarricense de ferrocariles) and the Promotion of Interurban Electric Train in the Great Metropolitan Area aims to modernize rail transportation in Costa Rica. It encourages the Incofer to electrify, rebuild, improve and extend the already existing railway network and allows it to take on debt up to a maximum equivalent to 40% of its assets (source: http://www.lse.ac.uk/GranthamInstitute/law/law-9366-on-railroad-electrification/)
Summary: The policy aims to modernize rail transportation in Costa Rica by strengthening the Costa Rican Railway Institute (Incofer). It encourages Incofer to electrify, rebuild, and expand the existing railway network. Additionally, it permits Incofer to incur debt up to 40% of its assets to support these initiatives.

policy_description:
By 2030, Madagascar aims to reduce its emissions to 48,403 Gg eq. CO2, a 28% decrease compared to the BAU scenario. In addition to this reduction in emissions, there will be an increase in the number of greenhouse gas sinks of the order of 20%, representing
avoided emissions and enhancement of carbon sinks in the order of 37,809 Gg eq. CO2 from LULUCF
Summary: By 2030, Madagascar plans to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions to 48,403 Gg eq. CO2, achieving a 28% decrease from the business-as-usual (BAU) scenario. (i) 2024 to 2028: 100 per cent
(ii) 2029 to 2034: 90 per cent
(iii) 2035 to 2039: 70 per cent
(iv) 2040 to 2044: 50 per cent

Summary:
The Kigali Amendment requires group II parties to peak their consumption of hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs) by 2024 and to gradually reduce it according to the following schedule: 
- 2024-2028: 100% of baseline consumption
- 2029-2034: 90% 
- 2035-2039: 70% 
- 2040-2044: 50% 
- 2045 and beyond: 20%

policy_description:
The Law on Saving Energy and Using Renewable Energies for Heating and Cooling in Buildings is the official title of this document. It replaces the Act for the Promotion of Renewable Energies in the Heat Sector (EEWärmeG), the Energy Conservation Act (Energieeinsparungsgesetz, EnEG), and the Energy Saving Ordinance (Energieinsparverordnung, EnEV). The new Buildings Energy Act lays forth specifications for how energy-efficient buildings must be, how energy performance certificates must be issued and used, and how renewable energy sources must be used in structures.
The Act was amended in 2022, and the change became effective at the start of 2023. The modified Act upped the requirements for new construction and lowered the yearly energy consumption cap from 75% to 55%.
Summary: The Law on Saving Energy and Using Renewable Energies for Heating and Cooling in Buildings replaces several previous acts and outlines requirements for energy-efficient buildings, the issuance and use of energy performance certificates, and the utilization of renewable energy sources. Amended in 2022 and effective from 2023, the updated legislation increases standards for new constructions and reduces the annual energy consumption limit from 75% to 55%.

policy_description: CREVI is a comprehensive roadmap aligning with various policies and programs to tackle EV industry challenges. It focuses on developing charging stations, manufacturing, R&D, and human resource development. With short-, medium-, and long-term targets, it aims to overcome barriers, unify public and private efforts, and achieve a 50% EV fleet by 2040 in a Clean Energy Scenario.

The roadmap includes short-, medium-, and long-term goals to eliminate obstacles and foster collaboration between public and private sectors, with the ultimate objective of achieving a 50% EV fleet by 2040 under a Clean Energy Scenario.

policy_description:
This EV Programme includes measures to increase the number of electric vehicles in New Zealand and has a goal of reaching approximately 64,000 electric vehicles by the end of 2021.
Measures include:
 Extending the Road User Charges exemption on light electric vehicles until they make up two percent of the light vehicle fleet
 A new Road User Charges exemption for heavy electric vehicles until they make up two percent of the heavy vehicle fleet
 $1 million annually for a nation-wide electric vehicle information and promotion campaign over five years;
 A contestable fund of up to $6 million per year to encourage and support innovative low emission vehicle projects.
Summary:
The EV Programme in New Zealand aims to boost the number of electric vehicles to approximately 64,000 by the end of 2021. Key measures include:

- Extending the Road User Charges exemption for light electric vehicles until they comprise 2% of the light vehicle fleet.
- Introducing a new Road User Charges exemption for heavy electric vehicles until they reach 2% of the heavy vehicle fleet.
- Allocating $1 million annually for a nationwide electric vehicle information and promotion campaign over five years.
